lead_paragraph: Former employees say that their managers warned them not to bend the rules, but they felt pressured by the bank’s aggressive sales culture to create fake accounts anyway.

byline.original: By MICHAEL CORKERY and STACY COWLEY

headline.print_headline: Warned About Excesses, Then Prodded to Sell
headline.main: Wells Fargo Warned Workers Against Sham Accounts, but ‘They Needed a Paycheck’

snippet: Former employees say that their managers warned them not to bend the rules, but they felt pressured by the bank’s aggressive sales culture to create fake accounts anyway....
abstract: Wells Fargo, despite warning employees not to set up sham bank accounts in name of unsuspecting clients, nevertheless pushed them on sales goals that caused workers to violate ethics training and bend rules anyway; chief exec John G Stumpf denies there was aggressive sales culture or unethical incentive system, and other bank officials say any occurrences of such behavior were caught and stopped as far back as 2013; 5,300 employees have lost jobs over scandal.
